articles.author: Chris Morris
articles.title: Coronavirus is affecting everything, even Diet Coke
articles.description: Coca-Cola warns of possible sweetener shortages for beverages including Diet Coke and Powerade if COVID-19 outbreak drags on.

articles.author: Naomi Xu Elegant
articles.title: Other countries are testing patients for coronavirus by the tens of thousands. Why the U.S. is so far behind
articles.description: South Korea has a coronavirus test drive-thru. China says its test can detect the virus in 15 minutes.

articles.author: James Nosek
articles.title: Federal Reserve cuts benchmark rate by half-point
articles.description: This occurs after seven major economies pledged to use “all appropriate tools" to deal with the spreading coronavirus.

articles.author: Ian Mount
articles.title: Rising pollution shows China factories bouncing back from coronavirus outbreak
articles.description: Nitrogen dioxide levels are rising across China’s industrial heartland. The reddish-brown gas mainly enters the air from burning fossil fuels like oil, coal and natural gas.

articles.author: Ian Mount
articles.title: Apple’s iPhone maker expects its China plants to be operating normally within weeks
articles.description: Hon Hai Precision Industry Co.—known as Foxconn—says its China plants should be operating normally by the end of March after resolving severe labor shortages brought on by the coronavirus outbreak.

articles.author: Dria Roland
articles.title: India restricts exports of common drugs on fear of coronavirus shortages
articles.description: India, the world’s largest maker of generic drugs, placed restrictions on the export of some common medicines as concerns grow over shortages of chemical ingredients with many manufacturers in China shut due to the novel coronavirus outbreak. The drugs includ…

articles.author: John Buysse
articles.title: It’s too late for the U.S. to fight the spread of coronavirus with domestic travel restrictions
articles.description: "This virus is already all around the country."

articles.author: Ian Mount
articles.title: The coronavirus outbreak could drag down debt-bloated companies. These are some of the most vulnerable
articles.description: An escalating outbreak that drives off customers and revenue could lead to ratings downgrades, hinder refinancing efforts, and in some cases trigger defaults.

articles.author: Sy Mukherjee
articles.title: Testing for coronavirus should be free, but it’s not always that simple
articles.description: The simple answer: It's complicated, and evolving.

articles.author: Danielle Abril
articles.title: Coronavirus concerns have Twitter ‘strongly encouraging’ its 5,000 worldwide employees to work from home
articles.description: The company is making sure internal meetings and other tasks "are optimized for remote participation."

articles.author: Dria Roland
articles.title: U.K. warns companies that 20% of workforce could be out as coronavirus cases rise
articles.description: As the number of confirmed infections in the U.K. rose to 51, the government published its plan for dealing with the disease. It included an estimate that in a worst-case, a fifth of the workforce—more than 6 million people—could be absent.
